docTitle.titlePart: An Organic Farmers Guide To Roundworm Biological Control In Sheep

titlePage.titlePart: Covers: What are roundworms? What are the symptoms? What is the life cycle of the parasites? What are the organic regulations? How do you control them? Easy to read, informative guide for controlling roundworms in your livestock to ensure you remain productive and don't miss out on that organic premium for your meat! By Part 3 RES Principles & Practice in Biological Control

p.s: - Round worms are common sheep parasite which predominately effect lambs, but also older ewes
- There are several species of roundworm & more than one species can be present in the same animal, however only one will be dominate
- There are two important diseases caused by roundworms:
Nematodirosis is when damage is caused by burrowing larvae in the gut.
Problems can be severe & can end in death.
Lambs can build residence to the parasite between 3 to 6 months of age.
Adult ewes are fully immune & don't carry N.battus worms, therefore cannot contaminate pasture

div2.head: Parasitic gastroenteritis (PGE) - caused by:Ostertagia, Trichostrongylus, & Nematodirus

p.s: PGE is the passing of tricostrongyloid eggs through the gut.
It causes energy & protein to be diverted away from vital processes such as meat, milk & wool production to repair the damaged gut & to maintain protein circulating in the blood

div1.head: What is the life cycle of the parasites?

p.s: Diagram 1 shows the life cycle for Nematodirus battus.
The 1 st, 2 nd & 3 rd stage larvae develop in the ground & are then consumed by the sheep
Diagram 2 shows the life cycle for Trichostrongylus.
Notice that the 3 rd stage larvae on the soil surface & are then consumed by the sheep
The regulations stipulate that preventative livestock management techniques are used instead of the prophylactic use of chemical medicinal products
A farm 'health plan' must be constructed to outline the appropriate measures to be taken if particular circumstances arise
Animals that become sick or injured must be treated by first using medicinal products that comply with organic farming principles; (plant extracts or plant, animal, mineral products)
If the above products don't work & the animal is in distress or is suffering, chemically synthesised medication may be administered, a record made and there is a legal 'withdrawal' period (28 days)

list.item: Select an appropriate breed - some breeds show great resistance, eg; Merino & Finn Dorset
Encourage the natural immunlogocial defences of the animal by: high quality feed, exercise & access to pasture
Host Immune Response - allowing some degree of exposure to promote resistance
Clean grazing by rotating animals between fields for grazing to achieve a balance where by problems with parasites are minimised & the life cycle for the nematodes are broken
Biological Fungus - a recently developed fungus which can be incorporated into feed supplement & break down the larvae stages of Trichostrongylus , once the eggs have been deposited in the dung

p.s: Clean grazing does not aim to eradicate roundworms but rather achieve an acceptable level of control based on the known ecology of the nematodes
Diagrams 1 & 2 show the cycle of both nematodes.

By rotating sheep between fields & ensuring that the 'new' field the sheep enter in the rotation has been free from grazing sheep, the likelihood of there being egg larvae present is small & therefore that field is deemed to be 'safe pasture'.

By carrying out this technique the life cycle of the nematode is broken & the threat posed by these parasites in a low input system are reduced, however, completely clean, uncontaminated land is impossible to achieve.
Acceptable larvae egg numbers:
Regular egg count samples should be taken from fresh dung.
Lab testing should identify the number of eggs per gram (EPG).
A good result would produce an EPG of >100, however an EPG of between 500-1000 will mean productivity losses will begin to become apparent, and EPG values <2000 will possibly result in lamb deaths.

A micro fungus known as Duddington flagrans has been found in recent studies to survive passing through the digestive tract of sheep & therefore is able to infect the egg larvae passed by the sheep & prevent the larvae spreading in the field.
Administered in sheep feed, this noval non-chemical approach would be well suited to organic livestock farmers if found to be economic.
